title: 104_s554
content: Equal access to justice reform is the focus of Section 1. The Act is titled "Equal Access to Justice Reform Amendments of 1995" and includes provisions for awarding costs and fees in administrative and judicial proceedings. The adjudicative officer or court may inquire if a party intends to seek fees and expenses against the agency in an adversary adjudication. The Act "Equal Access to Justice Reform Amendments of 1995" allows for awarding costs and fees in administrative and judicial proceedings. Parties may declare intent to seek fees and expenses against the agency. Hourly rates for attorney fees are set at $125 per hour unless a higher fee is justified by the cost-of-living increase at the date of final disposition. The Act "Equal Access to Justice Reform Amendments of 1995" allows for awarding costs and fees in administrative and judicial proceedings. Parties may declare intent to seek fees and expenses against the agency. An agency may offer a settlement of the claims made in the application for fees and expenses, which must be accepted within 10 days. If not accepted, the offer is deemed withdrawn. The Act allows for awarding costs and fees in administrative and judicial proceedings. An agency may offer a settlement of the claims made in the application for fees and expenses, which must be accepted within 10 days. If not accepted, the offer is deemed withdrawn. An agency may offer a settlement of the claims made in the application for fees and expenses, which must be accepted within 10 days. If not accepted, the offer is deemed withdrawn. If the applicant later obtains an award less favorable than the offer, they are not entitled to receive attorneys' fees or other expenses incurred after the date of the offer. The substantial justification standard is eliminated in administrative and judicial proceedings under Title 5 and Title 28 of the United States Code. This change removes the requirement for parties to allege that the agency's position was not substantially justified. The requirement to allege that the position of the United States was not substantially justified in administrative and judicial proceedings is eliminated. The determination of whether the position was substantially justified will be based on the record of the civil action. The Administrative Conference of the United States and the Department of Justice are required to submit reports to Congress analyzing fee awards paid by specific Federal agencies under section 504 of title 5, United States Code, and recommending extending the application of these sections to other Federal agencies and administrative proceedings. The Administrative Conference of the United States and the Department of Justice must submit reports to Congress analyzing fee awards paid by specific Federal districts under section 2412 of title 28, United States Code, with recommendations for extending the application of these sections to other Federal judicial proceedings. The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment and apply to administrative complaints filed with a Federal agency or civil actions filed in a United States court on or after that date.
